segments.text: Hello everybody and welcome to the special edition of the Christmas
Fireside Chat. I think last year Otto had a Christmas hat on or something, a party hat or something.
Now you didn't drop the ball. You see, Megan is too hard on herself,
but this is a very common characteristic of excellent people. They're hard on themselves.
Let's talk about Megan for the next 15 minutes and then bring in oxygen so as to revive her.
Anyway, we're releasing this day before Christmas and to those of you celebrating,
and I hope it's many of you, Mary Christmas, truly from the bottom of my heart. And I want to talk to
you about Christmas. I want to talk to you about the great battle in the West and in America
specifically and then take your questions. So let me say at the outset, I've said this in the past,
I don't know if on Fireside Chats or not, but I certainly have written about it and broadcast
about it. I am a religious practicing Jew and my favorite time of the year is Christmas time
and I see zero conflict in saying that. Christmas in America has been unbelievably special to me
since I was a child. As many of you know, I'm very into music, specifically classical music.
My second favorite music to Beethoven and Bach and so on is Christmas music.
Not just the Handel's Messiah. In other words, not just things that although Handel's Messiah would
be more addressed to Easter, but it's not just the classical, but I mean the great melodies created
in America between I'd say about 1925 and 1960. An astounding eruption of gorgeous Christmas music.
By the way, most or at least half of the biggest Christmas music hits were written by Jews.
To give you an idea of how appealing the Christmas season has been across religion and across
everything else that people might define themselves by.
And I have watched in my lifetime the demise of Christmas as essential,
apart as an essential part of American life, and it began with the dropping of Christmas for the
word holiday. You're intellectually dishonest if you do not acknowledge that that was a deliberate
attack on the specialness of Christmas. We don't say that about any other holiday. We say happy
Thanksgiving. We say happy Halloween. We say happy New Year, but with regard to Christmas,
we say happy holiday. Now why is that? Because they're of the of the deliberate attempt
to de-religionize the United States of America. I never say happy holidays. I don't respond to
happy holidays. I just respond with Merry Christmas. The idea that a non-Christian would be offended
by the words Merry Christmas is literally pathologic. If you are offended, if you are told Merry Christmas
and you happen not to be a Christian, there's something wrong with you. There's nothing wrong
with the person who said Merry Christmas. My listeners know that I am a Jew who observes,
if you will, Hanukkah. They wish me regularly Merry Christmas, and I am deeply touched that they do.
In Israel with the majority of Jews, you think they don't say,
Shanatovah, happy New Year, to non-Jews in Israel. Are they offended? I don't think so. They say
Shabbat Shalom. Shabbat Shalom is said on Israeli radio. It's a Jewish country, a country mostly of
Jews. And on the radio, as sunset takes place on Friday and the beginning of the Sabbath,
they wish their listeners Shabbat Shalom. Not happy holiday, not good Saturday, but Shabbat Shalom.
Shabbat peace. That's the traditional wish on the Sabbath. Are non-Jewish people who listen to
Israeli radio offended? So why is anybody offended by Merry Christmas? You are a narcissist
if you are offended by Merry Christmas. There is literally something morally and psychologically
wrong with you. I don't normally talk like this, but it's true. How can you be offended by a
beautiful wish? You don't observe it, so what? It happens to be a national holiday in the United
States of America. As far as the ACLU is concerned, we would drop that. I'll bet you if they were
voted in the among Democratic Party members of Congress, I don't think that they would yet have
the courage of their convictions and drop Christmas as a national holiday, but I'll bet a fair number

to kindness and devoted to, as it were, cheer and the special music and salvation army kettles,
collecting money for the poor, how could you not like that? What could be bad about that?
So I just wanted to say those words on behalf of this wonderful time of year, the wonderful music,
the wonderful feelings, the wonderful ambience. The other 11 months of the year are normal,
and we wanted to have something special. And it's being clobbered. What is this notion of the
Christmas party at work now called the holiday party? How offensive? That's offensive.
Thought the majority of your workers, wherever you work, observe or at least have something to do with Christmas,
your business will offend your employees if you have a Christmas party. I shake my head in
in the incredulity of it all, the incredulity of it all. When Donald Trump would say make America

clearly have no political end because he is presumably out of office.
And I would give this as an example. When people think make America great again,

I'm living proof that they do because this is 20 years of these fruitcakes. For all I know,

I'm Dennis Prager. Thank you for watching.
